title: Lie bialgebra structures on the twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra

title_detail.value: Lie bialgebra structures on the twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra

summary:
In this paper we investigate Lie bialgebra structures on the twisted
Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra. With the classifications of Lie bialgebra
structures on the Virasoro algebra, we determined such structures on the
twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra. Moreover, some general and useful results
are obtained. With our methods and results we also can easily to determine such
structures on some Lie algebras related to the twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro
algebra.

summary_detail.value:
In this paper we investigate Lie bialgebra structures on the twisted
Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra. With the classifications of Lie bialgebra
structures on the Virasoro algebra, we determined such structures on the
twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra. Moreover, some general and useful results
are obtained. With our methods and results we also can easily to determine such
structures on some Lie algebras related to the twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro
algebra.

author: Linsheng Zhu
arxiv_comment: Latex 18page. arXiv admin note: text overlap with arXiv:0901.1339
fulltext:
LIE BIALGEBRA STRUCTURES ON THE TWISTED
HEISENBERG-VIRASORO ALGEBRA

arXiv:1007.4055v3 [math.RA] 31 Mar 2012

DONG LIU, YUFENG PEI, AND LINSHENG ZHU

Abstract. In this paper we investigate Lie bialgebra structures on the twisted
Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra. With the determination of certain Lie bialgebra structures on the Virasoro algebra, we determine certain structures on the twisted Heisenberg -Virasoro algebra. Moreover, some general and useful results are obtained.
With our methods and results we also can easily to determine certain structures on
some Lie algebras related to the twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra.
Key words: Lie bialgebra, Yang-Baxter equation, twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra.
Mathematics Subject Classification (2000): 17B05, 17B37, 17B62, 17B68.
1. Introduction
Witt type Lie bialgebras were studied in [15, 16, 20, 17], whose generalized cases
were considered in [19, 21]. Lie bialgebra structures on some Lie (super)algebras
including the Schrödinger-Virasoro Lie algebra, the Lie algebra of Weyl type, the
N = 2 superconformal algebra, were investigated case by case in [8], [6], [24], [12],
[23], etc.. However, the calculations in these papers are very complicated. These
algebras are all related to the twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra, which has been
first studied by Arbarello et al. in [1], where a connection is established between the
second cohomology of certain moduli spaces of curves and the second cohomology
of the Lie algebra of differential operators of order at most one. Moreover, the
twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra has some relations with the full-toroidal Lie
algebras and the N = 2 super conformalalgebra, which is one of the most important
algebraic objects in superstring theory. The structure and representations for the
twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra was studied in [1], [2], [18], [14], [10] and [11] etc.
However, Lie bialgebra structures on the twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro Lie algebra
have not yet been considered. Drinfel'd [4] posed the problem whether or not there
exists a general way to quantize all Lie bialgebras. Although Etingof and Kazhdan
[5] gave a positive answer to the question, they did not provide a uniform method
to realize quantizations of all Lie bialgebras. As a matter of fact, investigating Lie
bialgebras and quantizations is a complicated problem.
1

 2

DONG LIU, YUFENG PEI, AND LINSHENG ZHU

In this paper, we shall obtain some Lie bialgebra structures on the twisted
Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra. Moreover we obtain some general results for this kinds
of Lie algebras and provide a uniform method (no need some complicated calculations) to obtain Lie (super)bialgebra structures on a series of Lie (super) algebras
related to twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra, including the Lie algebra of differential operators, the Schrödinger-Virasoro algebra, the N = 2 superconformal algebra,
etc..
We note that the center of the twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra is 4-dimensional,
which is different from the above algebras whose centers are no more than onedimensional. So our construction is new and it has the potential to construct more
Lie bialgebra structures.
Throughout the paper, we denote by Z+ the set of all nonnegative integers and
∗
Z (resp. C∗ ) the set of all nonzero elements of Z (resp. C).
2. Basics
2.1. The twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra. By definition, as a vector space
over C, the twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra L has a basis {Lm , Im , CL , CI , CLI |
m ∈ Z}, subject to the following relations:
[Lm , Ln ] = (n − m)Lm+n + δm+n,0

[Lm , In ] = nIm+n + δm+n,0 (m2 − m)CLI ;
[L, CL ] = [L, CI ] = [L, CLI ] = 0.

(2.1)

Clearly the Heisenberg algebra H = C{Im , CI | m ∈ Z} and the Virasoro
algebra v = C{Lm , CL | m ∈ Z} are subalgebras of L. Moreover, L = ⊕m∈Z Lm ,
where Lm = C{Lm , Im } ⊕ δm,0 C{CI , CL , CLI }, is a Z-graded Lie algebra. Clearly
Z = {I0 , CLI , CL , CI } is a basis of the center C of L.

Let G1 be subalgebra of the Lie algebra G of differential operators generated
by {tm , tm D | m ∈ Z}. Then G1 is isomorphic to the centerless twisted HeisenbergVirasoro algebra by tm D to Lm and tm to Im .

Let M be a Z-graded L-module. Denote by Der(L, M) the set of derivations
φ : L → M, namely, φ is a linear map satisfying
φ([x, y]) = x * φ(y) − y * φ(x),

(2.3)

and the set Inn(L, M) consisting of the derivations vinn , v ∈ M, where vinn is the
inner derivation defined by vinn : x 7→ x * v. Then it is well known that H 1 (L, M) ∼
=
Der(L, M)/Inn(L, M), where H 1 (L, M) is the first cohomology group of the Lie
algebra L with coefficients in the L-module M.
A derivation φ ∈ Der(L, M) is homogeneous of degree m ∈ Z if φ(Lp ) ⊂ Mm+p
for all p ∈ Z. Denote Der(L, M)m = {φ ∈ Der(L, M) | deg φ = m} for m ∈ Z. Let
φ be an element of Der(L, M). For any m ∈ Z, define the linear map φm : L → M
P

we set φm (u) = uq+m . Obviously, φm ∈ Der(L, M)m and we have

It is well known that L is the universal central extension of G1 (see [1]).

Lemma 2.1. [18] H 1 (L, L) = D, where D is consist of the following derivations χ:
χ(Ln ) = (αn + γ)In + δn,0 (γ + α)CLI ,
χ(In ) = βIn + δn,0 (α + γ)CI ,
χ(CL ) = −24αCLI , χ(CLI ) = βCLI − αCI , χ(CI ) = 2βCI ,
where α, β, γ ∈ C, n ∈ Z.
The following lemma is very useful to investigate Lie bialgebra structures for
some Lie algebras related to the Virasoro algebra.

DONG LIU, YUFENG PEI, AND LINSHENG ZHU


2.2. Lie bialgebras. Let us recall the definitions related to Lie bialgebras. Let L
be any vector space. Denote ξ the cyclic map of L⊗L⊗L, namely, ξ(x1 ⊗x2 ⊗x3 ) =
x2 ⊗ x3 ⊗ x1 for x1 , x2 , x3 ∈ L, and τ the twist map of L ⊗ L, i.e., τ (x ⊗ y) = y ⊗ x
for x, y ∈ L. The definitions of a Lie algebra and Lie coalgebra can be reformulated
as follows. A Lie algebra is a pair (L, δ) of a vector space L and a bilinear map
δ : L ⊗ L → L with the conditions:
Ker (1 − τ ) ⊂ Ker δ,

δ * (1 ⊗ δ) * (1 + ξ + ξ 2 ) = 0 : L ⊗ L ⊗ L → L.

Dually, a Lie coalgebra is a pair (L, ∆) of a vector space L and a linear map ∆ :
L → L ⊗ L satisfying:
Im ∆ ⊂ Im(1 − τ ),

(1 + ξ + ξ 2 ) * (1 ⊗ ∆) * ∆ = 0 : L → L ⊗ L ⊗ L. (2.5)

We shall use the symbol "*" to stand for the diagonal adjoint action:
P
P
x * ( ai ⊗ bi ) = ([x, ai ] ⊗ bi + ai ⊗ [x, bi ]).
i

i

A Lie bialgebra is a triple (L, δ, ∆) such that (L, δ) is a Lie algebra, (L, ∆) is a Lie
coalgebra, and the following compatible condition holds:
∆δ(x ⊗ y) = x * ∆y − y * ∆x, ∀ x, y ∈ L.

(2.6)

Denote U the universal enveloping algebra of L, and 1 the identity element of U.

Definition 2.3. (1) A coboundary Lie bialgebra is a 4-tuple (L, δ, ∆, r), where
(L, δ, ∆) is a Lie bialgebra and r ∈ Im(1 − τ ) ⊂ L ⊗ L such that ∆ = ∆r is a
coboundary of r, where ∆r is defined by
∆r (x) = x * r for x ∈ L.

(2.7)

(2) A coboundary Lie bialgebra (L, δ, ∆, r) is called triangular if it satisfies the
following classical Yang-Baxter Equation (CYBE):
c(r) = 0.

(2.8)

(3) An element r ∈ Im(1−τ ) ⊂ L⊗L is said to satisfy the modified Yang-Baxter
equation (MCYBE) if
x * c(r) = 0, ∀ x ∈ L.

(2.9)

Lemma 2.4. Regard L⊗n (the tensor product of n copies of L) as an L-module
under the adjoint diagonal action of L. Suppose r ∈ L⊗n satisfying x * r = 0, ∀
x ∈ L. Then r ∈ CL⊗n , where CL is the center of L.
Proof. It can be proved directly by using the similar arguments as those presented
in the proof of Lemma 2.2 of [22](also see the proof Lemma 2.5 of [9]).

Lemma 2.5. Let L be a Lie algebra and r ∈ Im(1 − τ ) ⊂ L ⊗ L, then
(1 + ξ + ξ 2 ) * (1 ⊗ ∆r ) * ∆r (x) = x * c(r), ∀ x ∈ L,

(2.10)

and the triple (L, [*, *], ∆r ) is a Lie bialgebra if and only if r satisfies MCYBE (2.9).
Proof. The result can be found in [3, 4, 17].



The Lie bialgebra structures over the Witt algebra W (the centerless Virasoro
algebra) and the Virasoro algebra v were determined in [17].
Proposition 2.6. [17, 19] For the Witt algebra W and the Virasoro algebra v,
H 1 (W, W ⊗ W ) = H 1 (v, v ⊗ v) = 0, and every Lie bialgebra structure on W or v is
triangular coboundary.
3. Lie bialgebra structures on the twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro
algebra
Regard V = L ⊗ L as a L-module under the adjoint diagonal action,then L and
V are both Z-graded. Now we shall calculate H 1 (L, V) for the twisted HeisenbergVirasoro algebra L with Proposition 2.6, and then determine Lie bialgebra structures
on the algebra.
For any 6 elements α, α†, β, β † , γ, γ † ∈ C and z1 , z1† , w1 , w1† ∈ Z, one can easily
verify that the linear map ̺ : L → V defined below is a derivation:

̺(CLI ) = (βw1 ⊗ CLI + β † CLI ⊗ w1† ) − (αz1 ⊗ CI + α† CI ⊗ z1† ),
̺(CI ) = 2(βw1 ⊗ CI + β † CI ⊗ w1† ), n ∈ Z, zi ∈ Z, i = 1, 2, 3, 4.

(3.1)

Clearly ̺ is an outer derivation of Der(L, L ⊗ L) if α, α†, β, β †, γ, γ † are not zeros.
Denote D the vector space spanned by the such elements ̺ over C. Let D 0 be the
subspace of D consisting of elements ̺ such that ρ(L) ⊆ Im(1 − τ ). Namely, D 0
is a subspace of D consisting of elements ̺ with α = −α† , β = −β † , γ = −γ † ,
z1 = z1† , w1 = w1† .
The main results of this paper can be formulated as follows.
Theorem 3.1.
(i) Der(L, V) = Inn(L, V) ⊕ D and H 1 (L, V) ∼
= D.
(ii) Let (L, [*, *], ∆) be a Lie bialgebra such that ∆ has the decomposition ∆r + σ
with respect to Der(L, V) = Inn(L, V) ⊕ D, where r ∈ V (mod C ⊗ C) and
σ ∈ D. Then, r ∈ Im(1 − τ ) and σ ∈ D 0 . Furthermore, (L, [*, *], σ) is a Lie
bialgebra provided σ ∈ D 0 .
Proof. For any φ ∈ Der(L, V), we first claim that if m ∈ Z∗ then φm ∈ Inn(L, V).
To see this, denote γ = m−1 φm (L0 ) ∈ Vm . Then for any xn ∈ Ln , applying φm to
[L0 , xn ] = nxn and using φm (xn ) ∈ Vn+m , we obtain (m + n)φm (xn ) − xn * φm (L0 ) =
L0 * φm (xn ) − xn * φm (L0 ) = nφm (xn ), i.e., φm (xn ) = γinn (xn ). Thus φm = γinn is
inner.
We can claim that φ(L0 ) ≡ 0(mod C ⊗ C). Indeed, for any p ∈ Z and xp ∈ Lp ,
applying φ to [L0 , xp ] = pxp , one has xp * φ(L0 ) = 0(mod C ⊗ C). Thus by Lemma
2.4, φ(L0 ) ≡ 0(mod C ⊗ C).
Now we claim that for any φ ∈ Der(L, V), (2.4) is a finite sum. To see this, one
can suppose φn = (wn† )inn for some wn† ∈ Vn and n ∈ Z∗ . If Z′ = {n ∈ Z∗ | wn† 6= 0} is
P
P
an infinite set, then φ(L0 ) = φ(L0 )+ n∈Z′ L0 *wn† = φ(L0 )+ n∈Z′ nwn† is an infinite

sum, which is not an element in V, contradicting the fact that φ is a derivation from
L to V. This together with Proposition 3.3, 3.4 below proves Theorem 3.1(i).
By definition, the algebra h = C{In , CI , CL , CLI | n ∈ Z} is an ideal of L.
Set H = L ⊗ h + h ⊗ L, then H is a L-submodule of V. The exact sequence

H 1 (L, K) = 0.
Proposition 3.2. H 1 (L, K) = 0.

W ) = 0.
Let f ∈ HomU (W ) (h, W ⊗ W ), for any n ∈ Z,

So f (CLI ) = 0. Similarly, f (I0 ) = f (CL ) = 0. Moreover, f (Im ) ∈ Vm since
f ([L0 , Im ]) = [L0 , f (Im )].
By f ([L−m , Im ]) = [L−m , f (Im )], we can suppose that f (Im ) = am (L2m ⊗ L−m −
3Lm ⊗ L0 + 3L0 ⊗ Lm − L−m ⊗ L2m ). Moreover by mf (In+m ) = [Ln , f (Im )] for any
n ∈ Z we obtain that am = 0 for all 0 6= m ∈ Z. Therefore, f = 0.

Now we shall determine H 1 (L, H). Denote by LC = L ⊗ C + C ⊗ L, then LC is
a L-submodule of H.The exact sequence 0 → LC → H → H/LC → 0 induces
→ H 0 (L, H/LC ) −→ H 1 (L, LC ) −→ H 1(L, H) −→ H 1 (L, H/LC ) → .
Clearly H 0 (L, H/LC ) = (H/LC )L = 0. Now we shall prove that H 1 (L, H/LC ) = 0,
then we have H 1 (L, LC ) ∼
= H 1 (L, H).
Proposition 3.3. H 1 (L, H/LC ) = 0.

For any φ ∈ Der(L, H/LC )0 , 0 6= n ∈ Z, one can write φ(Ln ) and φ(In ) as
follows

Applying φ to [ L2 , L−1 ] = −3L1 , and comparing the coefficient of Lp ⊗I1−p , Ip ⊗L1−p
and Ip ⊗ I1−p one can obtain that
a2,p = b2,p = b†2,p = 0.

Similarly by [L1 , L−2 ] = −3L−1 , we have a−2,p = 0 for all p ∈ Z. It follows from
this formula and (3.3)–(3.5) that φ(L±1 ) = φ(L±2 ) = 0. Thus for any n ∈ Z, one
can deduce φ(Ln ) = 0, since v can be generated by L±1 and L±2 . While for In , by
[L−n , In ] = nI0 and [Lm , In ] = nIm+n we have φ(In ) = 0.
Remark 1. The Proposition 3.2, 3.3 hold for many Lie algebras related to the
Virasoro algebra. For example, W (a, b) = C{Lm , In | m, n ∈ Z}, where Lm , Im , m ∈
Z are the centerless Virasoro, Heisenberg operators, and the twisted action is given
by [Lm , In ] = (a + bm + n)Im+n for all m, n ∈ Z and for some a, b ∈ C see [7] for
detail.
Proposition 3.4. H 1 (L, LC ) = D, where LC = C ⊗ L + L ⊗ C.

 LIE BIALGEBRA STRUCTURES ON THE TWISTED HEISENBERG-VIRASORO ALGEBRA 9

Proof of Proposition 3.4.
For any φ ∈ Der(L, LC )0 , n 6= 0, from Lemma 2.1, 2.2, we suppose that
φ(Ln ) = (nα + γ)z1 ⊗ In +(nα† + γ † )In ⊗z1† ,
φ(In ) = βw1 ⊗ In +β †In ⊗w1† ,

(3.6)

for some α, α† , β, β †, γ, γ † ∈ C.
By [L1 , L−1 ] = −2L0 we have
φ(L0 ) = γz1 ⊗ I0 + γ † I0 ⊗ z1† + (α + γ)z1 ⊗ CLI + (α† + γ † )CLI ⊗ z1† .

(3.7)

By [L1 , I−1 ] = −I0 we have
φ(I0 ) = βw1 ⊗ I0 + β † I0 ⊗ w1† + (α + γ)z1 ⊗ CI + (α† + γ † )CI ⊗ z1† .

(3.8)

Moreover CL , φ(CLI ) and φ(CI ) can be computed by [L2 , L−2 ] = −4L0 + 12 CL ,
[L−1 , I1 ] = I0 + 2CLI and [I1 , I−1 ] = −CI . Then we get φ ∈ D.



Proof of Theorem 3.1 (ii)

Let (L, [*, *], ∆) be a Lie bialgebra structure on L. By

(2.3), (2.6) and Theorem 3.1(i), ∆ = ∆r +σ, where r ∈ V (mod C ⊗C) and σ ∈ D. By
(2.5), Im ∆ ⊂ Im(1−τ ), so ∆r (Ln )+σ(Ln ) ∈ Im(1−τ ) for n ∈ Z, which implies that
α+α† = γ +γ † = 0. Similarly, β +β † = 0 by the fact that ∆r (In )+σ(In ) ∈ Im(1−τ )
for n ∈ Z. Thus, σ(L) ∈ Im(1 − τ ). So Im ∆r ∈ Im(1 − τ ). It follows immediately
from Lemma 3.5 that r ∈ Im(1 − τ ) (mod C ⊗ C), proving the first statement of
Theorem 3.1(ii). If σ ∈ D 0 , one can easily verify that (1 + ξ + ξ 2) * (1 ⊗ σ) * σ = 0
by acting it on generators of L, which shows (L, [*, *], σ) is a Lie bialgebra, and the
proof of Theorem 3.1(ii) is completed.

 LIE BIALGEBRA STRUCTURES ON THE TWISTED HEISENBERG-VIRASORO ALGEBRA 11

4. Lie bialgebra structures on some other Lie algebras
With the methods and results in Section 3, we can easily to obtain Lie bialgebra
structures on some other Lie algebras related the twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra. Although some of them were studied case by case in some papers (see [12],[8],
[6],[9], etc.), their calculations are very complicated.
4.1. Lie algebra of differential operators of order at most one. Let G1 be
the Lie algebra of differential operators of order at most one. Then G1 is just the
centerless twisted Heisenberg-Virasoro algebra.
As a vector space over C, G1 has a basis {Lm , Im , m ∈ Z}, subject to the
following relations:
[Lm , Ln ] = (n − m)Lm+n ,
[Im , In ] = 0,
[Lm , In ] = nIm+n .
Lemma 4.1. For the Lie algebra G1 and r ∈ G1 ⊗ G1 , r satisfies CYBE in (2.8) if
and only if it satisfies MCYBE in (2.9).
V
Remark 2. Let L be a Lie algebra such that H 0 (L; 3 L) = 0. Then any solution r ∈
V
L L of the MCYBE is actually a solution of CYBE. All the following Lie algebras
satisfy this condition, then Lemma 4.1 holds for all the following Lie algebras.
For any 6 elements α, α†, β, β †, γ, γ † ∈ C, one can easily verify that the linear
map ̺ : L → V defined below is a derivation:
̺(Ln ) = (nα + γ)I0 ⊗ In + (nα† + γ † )In ⊗ I0 ,
̺(In ) = βI0 ⊗ In + β † In ⊗ I0 .

(4.1)

Denote D1 the vector space spanned by the such elements ̺ over C. Let D10 be the
subspace of D1 consisting of elements ̺ such that D(L) ⊆ Im(1 − τ ). Namely, D10 is
a subspace of D1 consisting of elements ̺ with α = −α† , β = −β † , γ = −γ † .
According to the results in Section 3, we obtain the following result.
(i) Der(G1 , G1 ⊗ G1 ) = Inn(G1 , G1 ⊗ G1 ) ⊕ D1 and H 1 (G1 , G1 ⊗
G1 ) = Der(G1 , G1 ⊗ G1 )/Inn(G1 , G1 ⊗ G1 ) ∼
= D1 .
(ii) Let (G1 , [*, *], ∆) be a Lie bialgebra such that ∆ has the decomposition ∆r + σ
with respect to Der(G1 , G1 ⊗ G1 ) = Inn(G1 , G1 ⊗ G1 ) ⊕ D1 , where r ∈ G1 ⊗

Theorem 4.2.

(L, [*, *], σ) is a Lie bialgebra provided σ ∈ D10 .

DONG LIU, YUFENG PEI, AND LINSHENG ZHU

(iii) A Lie bialgebra (G1 , [*, *], ∆) is triangular coboundary if and only if ∆ is an
inner derivation (thus ∆ = ∆r , where r ∈ Im(1 − τ ) is a solution of CYBE).
Proof. 4.2(iii) follows immediately from (2.5), Definition 2.3 and Lemma 4.1.
4.2. The Lie algebra of differential operators. Now we consider Lie bialgebra
structures on the Lie algebra of differential operators defined in Section 2. Although
such works for the Lie algebra of Weyl type (including the centerless Lie algebra of
differential operators) was consider in [24], our calculation is very simple. Clearly
Cd = C{1} is the center of G. Moreover, we have
Lemma 4.3. G is generated by {t, t−1 , D 2 }(see [25]).
For any 2 elements α, α† ∈ C, one can easily verify that the linear map ζα,α† :
G → G ⊗ G defined below is a derivation:
ζα,α† (tm ) = 0,
ζα,α† (tm D n ) = αntm D n−1 ⊗ 1 + α† n * 1 ⊗ tm D n−1 , ∀m ∈ Z, n ∈ Z+ . (4.2)
Clearly ζα,α† is an outer derivation of Der(G, G ⊗ G) if α, α† are not zeros.
Denote Dd the vector space spanned by the such elements ζα,α† over C. Let Dd0
be the subspace of Dd consisting of elements ζα,α† such that ζα,α† (G) ⊆ Im(1 − τ ).
Namely, Dd0 is a subspace of Dd consisting of elements σ with α = −α† .
With the results in Section 3, we can obtain the main results of this paper as
follows.
Theorem 4.4. (i) Der(G, G ⊗ G) = Inn(G, G ⊗ G) ⊕ Dd and H 1 (G, G ⊗ G) ∼
= Dd .
(ii) Let (G, [*, *], σ) be a Lie bialgebra such that σ has the decomposition ∆r + σ
with respect to Der(G, G ⊗ G) = Inn(G, G ⊗ G) ⊕ Dd , where r ∈ G ⊗ G (mod Cd ⊗ Cd )
and σ ∈ Dd . Then, r ∈ Im(1 − τ ) and σ ∈ Dd0 . Furthermore, (G, [*, *], σ) is a Lie
bialgebra provided σ ∈ Dd0 .
(iii) A Lie bialgebra (G, [*, *], ∆) is triangular coboundary if and only if ∆ is an
inner derivation (thus ∆ = ∆r , where r ∈ Im(1 − τ ) is some solutions of CYBE).
Proof. For any σ ∈ Der(G, G ⊗ G), we can suppose that σ(t) = 0(see [24], or [25]).
With [tm , t] = 0 and [tm D, t] = tm+1 , we have σ(tm ), σ(tm D) ∈ G1 ⊗ G1 . Then we
have
Der(G1 , G ⊗ G) ⊂ Der(G1 , G1 ⊗ G1 ) + Inn(G1 , G ⊗ G)

4.3. The Schrödinger-Virasoro Lie algebra. The Schrödinger-Virasoro algebra
sv, playing important roles in mathematics and statistical physics, is a infinitedimensional Lie algebra first introduced by M. Henkle in [6] by looking at the invariance of the free Schrödinger equation in (1+1)dimensions: (2M∂t − ∂r2 )ψ = 0.
The structure and the representation theory for it have been well studied by many
authors (see [8], [13], etc.).
The Schrödinger-Virasoro Lie algebra sv is the infinite-dimensional Lie algebra
sv with C-basis {Ln , In , Yr |n ∈ Z, r ∈ Z + 21 } and the following relations
[Lm , Ln ] = (n − m)Lm+n + δm+n,0
[Ln , Yr ] = (r −

n
)Yn+r ,
2

[Lm , In ] = nIm+n ,
[Yr , Ys ] = (s − r)Ir+s ,
[Yr , Ip ] = [In , Ip ] = 0.

(m3 − m)C,

where m, n ∈ Z, r, s ∈ Z + 21 .
Clearly Cs = C{I0 , C} is the center of sv. Denote Zs by the set {I0 , C}.
Lie bialgebra structures over the cenreless Schrödinger-Virasoro Lie algebra
(C = 0) were determined in [8]. However, using the methods and results in Section
3, the original proof in [8] can be greatly simplified.
For any 6 elements α, a† , β, β †, γ, γ † ∈ C, z1 , z1† , w1, w1† ∈ Zs , one can easily
verify that the linear map ρ : sv → sv ⊗ sv defined below is a derivation:
ρ(Ln ) = (nα + γ)z1 ⊗ In + (nα† + γ † ))In ⊗ z1† ,
ρ(In ) = 2(βw1 ⊗ In + β † In ⊗ w1† ),
ρ(Yn− 1 ) = βw1 ⊗ Yn− 1 + β † Yn− 1 ⊗ w1† ,

the subspace of Ds consisting of elements ρ with α = −α† , β = −β † , γ = −γ † and
z1 = z1† , w1 = w1† .
Theorem 4.5. (The centerless case was given in [8])
(i) Der(sv, sv ⊗ sv) = Inn(sv, sv ⊗ sv) ⊕ Ds and H 1 (sv, sv ⊗ sv) = Der(sv, sv ⊗
sv)/Inn(sv, sv ⊗ sv) ∼
= Ds .
(ii) Let (sv, [*, *], ∆) be a Lie bialgebra such that ∆ has the decomposition ∆r +σ
with respect to Der(sv, sv⊗sv) = Inn(sv, sv⊗sv)⊕Ds , where r ∈ sv⊗sv (mod C ⊗C)
and σ ∈ Ds . Then, r ∈ Im(1 − τ ) and D ∈ Ds0 . Furthermore, (sv, [*, *], σ) is a Lie
bialgebra provided σ ∈ Ds0 .
(iii) A Lie bialgebra (sv, [*, *], ∆) is triangular coboundary if and only if ∆ is an
inner derivation (thus ∆ = ∆r , where r ∈ Im(1 − τ ) is a solution of CYBE).

Denote by Y = C{Yr | r ∈ Z + 21 }, then Y is a L-module. From the proof of the
Theorem 4.4, we obtain the following result, which is very useful in determining Lie
bialgebra (super-bialgebra) structures on some Lie (super) algebras, for example,
the N = 2 superconformal Neveu-Schwarz algebra, etc..
Corollary 4.6. H 1 (v, Y ⊗ Y ) = H 1 (L, Y ⊗ Y ) = 0.

Remark 4. We can also use the above ideas to determine Lie bialgebra structures
on some other Lie algebras and Lie superalgebras related to the twisted HeisenbergVirasoro algebra, for example, the twisted Schrödinger-Virasoro Lie algebra (for
